newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Hungary says studying Malaysia privatisation.
newsitem.headline: Hungary says studying Malaysia privatisation.

text.p: Hungary is interested in Malaysia's privatisation programme and wants to enhance economic ties, Malaysia's defence minister said on Monday.

Hungarian Prime Minister Gyula Horn expressed interest in the privatisation programme during a meeting with his Malaysian counterpart Mahathir Mohamad, Defence Minister and acting Foreign Minister Syed Hamid Albar told reporters afterward.
Malaysia has listed a number of state companies on the local stock exchange and awarded other state entities to well-capitalised businessmen.

"Hungary would also like to see more participation from Malaysian investors in its economy which is undergoing a transition period from a state-run to an open market economy," the national news agency Bernama quoted Syed Hamid as saying.
Horn arrived in Kuala Lumpur on Monday for a two-day official visit.
Syed Hamid said Hungary offered expertise in tourism development to Malaysia and wanted to learn of Malaysia's experience in developing technology parks.
Horn invited Malaysian investors to come to Hungary. Malaysia currently has only one bank and one electronics company operating in the central European country.
Malaysia-Hungary trade totalled US$62.8 million in 1996, up 76 percent from US$46.5 million in 1995, a Hungarian official accompanying Horn said.
